qas.question: What US president was critical of Egypt's repression of Muslim Brotherhood?
How many individuals did one judge in Minya governatorate court sentence to death in April 2013?
What was the criticism of judge Mohammad NAgi Shatata sentence of 188 member of Muslim Brotherhood for assaulting police station?

answers.text: lack of fair trials, that often last only a few minutes

context: After Morsi was ousted by the military, the judiciary system aligned itself with the new government, actively suopporting the repression of Muslim Brotherhood members. This resulted in a sharp increase in mass death sentences that arose criticism from the <a0_0>US president Barack Obama<a0_0/> and the General Secretary of the UN, Ban Ki Moon. In April 2013, one judge of the Minya governatorate of Upper Egypt, sentenced <a1_0>1,212<a1_0/> people to death. In December 2014 the judge Mohammed Nagi Shahata, notorious for his fierceness in passing on death sentences, condemened to the capital penalty 188 members of the Muslim Brotherhood, for assaulting a police station. Various Egyptian and international human rights organisations have already pointed out the <a2_0>lack of fair trials, that often last only a few minutes<a2_0/> and do not take into consideration the procedural standards of fair trials.
